content.webTitle: Rolling Stone walks back UVA rape story over 'discrepancies' in student's account

fields.headline: Rolling Stone walks back UVA rape story over 'discrepancies' in student's account
fields.bodyText: Rolling Stone is walking back and apologizing for an explosive article it published about rape at the University of Virginia, admitting there “now appear to be discrepancies” in the key story in the article, about a woman who alleges that she was the victim of a calculated gang rape that took place by members of a fraternity at the school. In addition, in a lengthy investigation it published on Friday, based in part on interviews with the alleged victim, her friends, the accused and fraternity members, the Washington Post reported that some “close friends” of the woman in question, who are themselves advocates for victims of sexual assault, “said they believe something traumatic happened to [her] but have come to doubt her account” and noted several other important problems with Rolling Stone’s work. Rolling Stone’s original article was an expose about rape at UVA that centered around the alleged gang rape of a first-year student, “Jackie,” in an upstairs room of the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity house in 2012, and detailed how the administration failed, at several turns, to respond to the alleged incident. It garnered worldwide attention and prompted a swift response by the university and, reportedly, an investigation by local police. But the article, published amid national scrutiny of and a federal crackdown on the way colleges and universities handle sexual assault on campus, was also met with skepticism in parts of the media. In a statement published online on Friday, Rolling Stone’s managing editor Will Dana wrote: “In the face of new information, there now appear to be discrepancies in Jackie’s account, and we have come to the conclusion that our trust in her was misplaced. We were trying to be sensitive to the unfair shame and humiliation many women feel after a sexual assault and now regret the decision to not contact the alleged assaulters to get their account. We are taking this seriously and apologize to anyone who was affected by the story.” Responding on Twitter to the mounting criticism Friday afternoon, Dana said he found it “deeply unsettling” that Rolling Stone published an article he didn’t have “complete confidence” in, and that he couldn’t explain the discrepancies between the reported story and the fraternity’s statement. “We should have either not made this agreement with Jackie or worked harder to convince her that the truth would have been better served by getting the other side of the story. That failure is on us – not on her,” he wrote. Some media critics had questioned the reporting methods, scrutinizing the degree to which the magazine relied on a single source, Jackie, and the reporter Sabrina Rubin Erdely’s failure to contact the men accused of carrying out the attack. “For the sake of Rolling Stone’s reputation, Sabrina Rubin Erdely had better be the country’s greatest judge of character,” the Washington Post’s media critic, Erik Wemple, wrote on Tuesday. In the statement, Dana explained the magazine’s editorial decision not to reach out to the accused. “Because of the sensitive nature of Jackie’s story, we decided to honor her request not to contact the man she claimed orchestrated the attack on her nor any of the men she claimed participated in the attack for fear of retaliation against her,” he wrote. Over the course of several interviews with the Washington Post, Jackie defended her version of events and recounted a similar story, the paper reports. According to the paper, she said had been invited to a date party by a member of the fraternity, was lured into a room by her date and was brutally attacked by seven men while two watched. “I never asked for this,” she told the Post. “What bothers me is that so many people act like it didn’t happen. It’s my life. I have had to live with the fact that it happened every day for the last two years.” The fraternity also released a statement Friday afternoon. In it, the fraternity denied having hosted “a date function or a social event” on the weekend in September of 2012 when the gang rape is alleged to have taken place, said that it would not have been initiating new members during the fall semester – the Rolling Stone story implied that the rape was an initiation ritual – and said “no ritualized sexual assault is part of our pledging or initiation process,” calling that a “vile” idea. The UVA chapter of Phi Kappa Psi has suspended all operations while the investigation takes place. The fraternity said it is assisting local police with the investigation. Charlottesville police captain Gary Pleasants said: “Our purpose is to find the truth in any matter and that’s what we are looking for here. These articles do not change our focus moving forward.” The paper also reported that the name of one of the men Jackie alleges attacked her turned out to be similar to the name of a student who belonged to a different fraternity. This man, a UVA graduate, told the Post he had worked at the school’s Aquatic and Fitness Center – a detail Jackie provided in her account of the alleged rape, and that Rolling Stone had published – but said he had never met Jackie in person and that he was not a member of Phi Kappa Psi. In its statement, the fraternity said none of its members had worked at the facility during the time period in question.
